SEARCH
Module io.jstach.rainbowgum
Package io.jstach.rainbowgum

Interface LogOutput

All Superinterfaces:
AutoCloseable, Flushable, LogLifecycle
All Known Subinterfaces:
FileOutput, LogOutput.ThreadSafeLogOutput
All Known Implementing Classes:
ListLogOutput, LogOutput.AbstractOutputStreamOutput, RabbitMQOutput
public interface LogOutput extends LogLifecycle, Flushable
A resource that can be written to usually in binary. In other logging frameworks this is often called an "Appender" not be confused with RainbowGum's appenders. LogOutputs will be written synchronously by the appender either through locks or some other mechanism so other than output external specific locking (e.g file locking or db transaction) the output does not have to deal with that. In other words there will be no overlapping write calls as the appender and publisher combo promises that.

To simplyfy flushing and corruption prevention each call to the write methods MUST be the contents of the entire event!

The write methods do not throw IOException on purpose as it is implementations responsibility to handle errors and to be resilient on their own.

See Also:
  • LogOutput.OutputProvider
  • LogEncoder.Buffer
API Note
if for some reason the output needs to share events with other threads call LogEvent.freeze() which will return an immutable event.

    • ofStandardOut

      static LogProvider<LogOutput> ofStandardOut()
      Standard out output. The default implementation uses whatever is set to System.out at provision time. If System.out is rebound the output will not be updated!
      Returns:
      output.

    • write

      default void write(LogEvent[] events, int count, LogEncoder encoder)
      Write a batch of events by default calls write(LogEvent[], int, LogEncoder, Buffer). DO NOT MODIFY THE ARRAY. Do not use the length of the passed in array but instead use count parameter.
      Parameters:
      events - an array guaranteed to be smaller than count.
      count - the number of items.
      encoder - encoder to use for encoding.

    • write

      default void write(LogEvent[] events, int count, LogEncoder encoder, LogEncoder.Buffer buffer)
      Write a batch of events reusing the provided buffer and by default calling write(LogEvent, Buffer) for each event synchronously.

      The batching is usually a result of an asynchronous publisher so the maximum size is configured there with bufferSize. If this method is implemented there are some caveats.

      DO NOT MODIFY THE ARRAY. It is reused. Do not use the length of the passed in array but instead use count parameter. Consequently do not share the array or buffer with other threads however individual events can be shared by calling LogEvent.freeze() to guarantee that which is a safe no-op if it is already immutable.

      If the output plans on grouping the events into a single blob (byte array or byte buffer) a different output can be passed to the encoder other than itself (which is the default).

      Parameters:
      events - an array guaranteed to be smaller than count.
      count - the number of items.
      encoder - encoder to use for encoding.
      buffer - buffer to reuse. Do not share it with other threads!
      API Note
      If the output wants to fan-out or encode with other threads the buffer passed should not be used and instead LogEncoder.buffer(BufferHints) should be called to get a new buffer for each thread. This is generally not desirable for most resources such as a file or database as sending a batch is much faster (single writer principle).

    • write

      default void write(LogEvent event, LogEncoder.Buffer buffer)
      Writes a prepared buffer and by default drains the buffer to this output.
      Parameters:
      event - event.
      buffer - buffer that is already filled. Do not share it with other threads!
      API Note
      the buffer already has the encoding.

    • bufferHints

      default LogEncoder.BufferHints bufferHints()
      Hints to the buffer like what write style of the output and maximum buffer size. The output should still honor all write methods but this signals to the encoder which style it prefers.
      Returns:
      write mode.

    • reopen

      default LogResponse.Status reopen()
      Attempts to reopen the output if supported and SHOULD only be called by the appender! This call is mainly used for external log rotation systems such as logrotate or an aggregator agent.
      Returns:
      status and the default implementation will return LogResponse.Status.StandardStatus.IGNORED.
